III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Supervision.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12505
Section (1) An agency shall provide supervision for a youth in independent
Description living consistent with the youth's need for supervision, as required
by R 400.12504(2)(e).
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Allegation 1: Two youths in the home are selling drugs to two
other youths, who have special needs (one youth is pregnant in a
2

wheelchair and the other has seizures). The administrator is
aware of this and not acting on it.
Allegation 2: Social Worker 1, Chief Administrator 1 and staff do
not stop fights from happening at the facility.
Investigation Allegation 1
Interviews:
Complainant X
On 1/19/2023 I interviewed Complainant X by telephone.
Complainant X reported living at the Our House program from
September of 2022 until July of 2023. Complainant X mainly
reported indirect information related to the allegations. She
reported knowing things by way of her continued contact with
current and prior youths of Our House. She reported knowing
which youths live at the facility, that youths at the facility are
selling marijuana, but she was unsure who was buying the drugs.
She reported knowing one of the youth drugs are being sold to is
pregnant and in a wheelchair; and another has seizures. She said
when she lived at the facility Youth G gave her marijuana. She
reported this occurred sometime during the winter of 2022.
Complainant X reported Youth G was also either selling or giving
marijuana to other youths in the house. She said she knew about
this because another youth (Complainant X did not identify that
youth) would share the marijuana with her and that youth told her
the marijuana was from Youth G. Complainant X did not report
relaying this information to the Our House staff.
Complainant X reported she was also told that Youth D is selling
cocaine and Xanax. Complainant X admitted she never witnessed
such action by any youth when she lived there. Additionally, she
reported Youth C uses weed and vapes; and that he and other
youths (no other additional youth named) sell drugs. She reported
knowing Chief Administrator 1 and Social Worker 2 are aware of
youths using and selling drugs because they caught her smoking
marijuana once when she lived there, and they had walked in on
other youths smoking marijuana in their rooms; or had smelled the
drug coming from the youth’s room.
I asked Complainant X what staff did when the youths were
caught using or having drugs. Complainant X reported there are
consequences for the behavior. The staff take away the marijuana
or vape, and there is a week house restriction. She reported one
can also get kicked out of the program for continue use of
substances because it’s a violation of the facility rules, but that the
facility gives youths lots of chances. Complainant X reported at
least one youth had been kicked out of the program, but she
added that this youth had other additional house rule offenses.
3

She reported Youth XY used to live at the facility and may have
information about who was selling drugs at the house.
Youth XY
On 1/29/2024 I interviewed Youth XY by telephone. Youth XY
reported living at the facility from April 2022 until October 2023.
He reported only knowing that Youth G would sell marijuana in the
community, never at the facility. He denied ever witnessing Youth
G, or any youth giving or selling marijuana to Youth A or Youth B.
Youth XY reported, though he never witnessed it, he knew of
Youth G giving marijuana to Youth C. He said he knew that
because Youth C and Youth G got caught with it. Also, because
he had smelled marijuana when Youth C, Youth F and Youth G
were in Youth C’s room. He said the staff knew of youth using
drugs, because the staff had caught them with marijuana and
edibles. He said catching youth with those items was an ongoing
issue. Staff would tell the youth not to use drugs, that if they did
so in the community there wasn’t anything they could do about
that, but to not use it in the house. Staff would do room checks,
and if they smelled it or found it they would talk with the youth,
take the substance and would put the youth on restriction. Youth
XY did not know whether the staff reported any of those incidents
to the youth’s worker or sought out substance abuse services if
the youth needed them. Youth XY said he does not do drugs, so
he could only speculate that the staff may have done those things.
He reported knowledge of Youth J, and that Youth J was kicked
out of the program, but he did not know if it was for drug use or if
Youth J was doing other things.
Chief Administrator 1
On 1/24/2024 and 1/26/2024 I spoke with Chief Administrator (CA)
1 about the complaint allegations by telephone. She reported
some of their youths have substance issues. Therefore, some
things in the complaint may technically be true, in that they have
caught youths smoking marijuana in their rooms or with drug
paraphernalia. She reported she is not aware of any youths
selling marijuana, Xanax or cocaine to any youths. Nor had any
youth or staff reported such allegation to her. She reported it is
not true that they do not supervise their youths or that they allow
or condone drug use. She reported it is an independent living
program and they have limited control on what a youth does every
hour of the day. Staff supervises the youths from 4:00pm-8:00am.
They report concerns when they discover them and address those
concerns with the youth. CA 1 said they provide ongoing support
and supervision to the youths. They conduct random room checks
in an attempt to keep drugs out the house and dissuade drug use.
4

If they catch a youth smoking/using marijuana or in possession of
drugs on the premises they talk with the youth about their
behavior and the rules, ask for the items, and get the youth’s
worker or counselor involved by way of reporting or scheduling a
TDM (Team Decision meeting) or FTM (Family Team Meeting) if
necessary.
CA 1 advised current youths, Youth E, Youth D, and Youth C as
well as past youth, Youth G, had been caught smoking marijuana
in their rooms in the past. Youth E was also caught in possession
of a vape pen. She reported it had also been rumored by one
youth that Youth G was getting or selling marijuana in the
community, but that was never confirmed by the youth. Nor
something the agency staff ever witnessed or had knowledge of.
CA 1 further advised that Youth C and Youth E have substance
issues. Youth E is in treatment, and when he was caught with a
vape pen within the last month, the item was confiscated, his
counselor and worker were contacted and a TDM is pending. CA
1 reported Youth C is transitionally out of the program, and
although they had suspected him of using, when they caught him
it was the first time he was caught using. They talked him about
his behavior and were trying to get him to agree to work with his
counselor. They also reached out to his tribal social worker.
CA 1 reported as it relates to allegation pertaining to Youth D, who
is relatively new to Our House, Youth D was connected to Xanax,
but not for selling it, or selling cocaine. Youth D’s connection to
Xanax came to the agency’s attention as her possibly giving pills
to another youth (Youth H who was discharged from the program
in July 2023) who reportedly tried to hurt herself by taking pills.
Youth D knew the milligrams of the of the pills Youth H had taken
and Xanax were found in Youth H’s system. However, a search of
the youths rooms by staff did not discovery any Xanax or pills. CA
1 surmised that the youth who made this current complaint is a
past youth making the allegation up about the Xanax being sold.
CA 1 reported Youth D was also caught twice using marijuana. At
the time of the incidents, the marijuana was taken, and house
rules were re-discussed with Youth D. A TDM referral was also
completed and a substance abuse intake referral via Community
Mental Health (CMH) was completed for Youth D.
As for the cocaine allegation, CA 1 reported having no idea as to
where that allegation originated, as no youth has ever reported
such a thing. She reported there had been a rumor last year that
Youth J, (a prior youth of Our House) was offered and smoked
5

crack once while in the community but that incident was never
reported directly to the staff or confirmed.
CA 1 denied Youth A or Youth B reporting any youths giving or
selling them drugs. CA 1 said Youth B does not smoke marijuana.
Youth B was in treatment in the past, and since the summer of
2023, Youth B has done well. Youth B never reported purchasing
marijuana, or other drugs from anyone in the house. As for Youth
A, Youth A is pregnant, does use a wheelchair, has a TBI
(Traumatic Brain Injury) and other issues. Youth A denied any
recent drug use. CA 1 did not know if Youth A ever brought
marijuana in the house for use. CA 1 indicated the staff never
found anything. CA 1 reported once Youth A is ready for
discharge, Youth A will not be returning to Our House. Youth A will
need 24-hour care due to Youth A’s stress, high need pregnancy,
and other issues.
Social Worker 2
On 1/22/2024 I spoke with Social Worker (SW) 2 about the
complaint allegations by telephone. Another interview occurred
with SW 2 at the Our House’s administrative office on 1/29/2024.
SW 2 is the assigned case worker for all the youths placed in the
Our House home. Those youths (are all age 18, except Youth D)
are:
• Youth A who is hospitalized and cannot have visitors)
placed at Our House on 3/30/2023.
• Youth B placed at Our House on 3/29/2023.
• Youth C placed at Our House on 10/21/2022.
• Youth D placed at Our House on 11/27/2023.
• Youth E placed at Our House on 10/20/23.
• Youth F placed at Our House on 4/20/2023.
SW 2 affirmed that Youth G is a past Our House youth. Youth G
visits the house once or twice a month; because he dates Youth
F. Youth G is never allowed to stay over. SW 2 denied knowledge
of any youth selling marijuana to another, but reported there was a
time during staff room checks that marijuana was found in Youth
A, Youth C and Youth D’s room. Staff has also caught Youth C
and Youth D either using marijuana, or with marijuana or vapes,
“lots of vapes” in their rooms. SW 2 reported room checks are
conducted often, perhaps three times a month. The room checks
are situational, conducted by staff, when someone smells the
substance, it’s use is directly reported by someone, or staff gets a
tip about such. SW 2 reported all youths are provided the house
policy against drug use/ it being on the property and are aware of
the possible room checks. She reported when a youth is caught
6

using or with items, they confiscate the items, have a TDM about
the incident and the youth is placed on restriction, whereby, they
are limited in their access from the house without a staff until such
time that a TDM is held with the department. She reported there
are levels of reaction/consequences that occur about an incident.
On a first occurrence/offense, it would result in her being
contacted; and her having a discussion with the youth about
his/her/their behavior/the situation. On a second and or third
occurrence that would result in a meeting with her and CA 1.
Thereon, if there are more occurrences, the department monitor
would be involved in a TDM. They also document the incidents.
She reported with Youth C, he was involved in court order
therapy, which included addressing substance and drug screens,
but Youth C had only complied once.
Youths and Staff
On 1/29/2024 I interviewed Youth B, Youth C, Youth D and Youth
E onsite at the Our House independent living home. I also
interviewed Staff 3, and Staff 4 onsite on this date. I was unable to
interview Youth A.
• Youth A was unable to be interviewed by me. Youth A
was hospitalized and on bed and visitor restriction during
the course of this investigation.
• Youth C reported living in the independent living (IL) home
for one year and two months. He reported there are no
people in the house giving or selling marijuana to another.
He reported if any youth wants marijuana that person can
get it off the street. He said pretty much every youth has
gotten caught with marijuana at least once; inclusive of
himself recently. He said staff may be too nice around
giving youth too many chances, but staff do not allow any
youth to smoke or use drugs in the house. Staff talks to
them about not using drugs and following the rule. Staff do
room checks monthly and usually finds marijuana or
smoking devices. He said if caught in violation of the
house rules, there is a consequence for it, like restriction
and their worker will get contacted. He thinks staff should
be stricter, though admitted if a youth continues to violate
the rules the youth can get terminated from the program.
Youth C denied knowing any youth who sold or may have
sold Xanax or cocaine to any youth. He admitted hearing a
rumor about someone selling Xanax but denied knowing
who that could be.
7

• Youth B reported living in the IL home for 10 months. She
said she used to smoke weed, but she has been sober for
five-six months now. She reported there are youth in the
home using things like weed, Percocet, Adderall and
Xanax, but no one has given it to her or tried to sell it to
her. She said things like that may go on in the house, but
staff can’t catch everything. She said staff have found all
kinds of things in youths room, but mostly weed. She
reported there was one youth (whose name she would not
disclose) had Xanax and flushed them down the toilet after
a youth was taken to the hospital and it was discovered the
youth had taken Xanax. Youth B reported no one forces
another youth to use or smoke drugs, or to buy weed or
other substances. That if the other person wanted to use
the drug they would. She reported the staff may not
always follow up on what may be happening when the staff
smell weed, or when she has reported an issue. She
acknowledged not knowing whether the staff may have
followed up later. She said other youth and staff reported
staff finding paraphernalia during periodical room
searches. Youth B was not sure if those searches were
connected to staff having smelled marijuana. She admitted
youths are given consequences for breaking the house
rules about using drugs on the premises.
Youth B reported most of the time the youths in the home
are just using substances to get high not because they
have a drug problem. She did not know if staff have tried to
help youths to obtain substance treatment by referral or
had contact with others related to the youth’s behavior but
reported the staff did do so with her. They helped her with
a therapy referral and treatment.
• Youth D reported living in the IL house for two months.
She also denied any knowledge of any staff allowing any
youths to openly use drugs. She confirmed what other
youths reported about confiscation of drug paraphernalia
items and youth consequences. She also reported
everyone in the program may have an issue with drug use
and the staff tries to help them. She reported if staff think
you are using drugs or they find marijuana or
paraphernalia in a youth’s room, the agency conducts a
TDM, and safety plan, by asking if this is the right place for
the youth. She reported knowing this because it happened
with her. She reported speaking with CA 1 and SW 2,
8

having a TDM with her and her worker, and they placed
her on restriction as opposed to kicking her out, after
Youth H (who is no longer in the program) accused her of
selling Youth H narcotics. Youth D said that allegation
against her was false, that she never had Xanax.
Youth D reported knowing Youth G, but only in the context
of him visiting and hanging out with Youth F at the house
three times. She denied any awareness of Youth G or any
youths in the house selling drugs to Youth A, Youth B or
any other youths. She said Youth A keeps to herself and
has her own way of getting drugs.
• Youth E reported living in the IL home for three month. He
denied any knowledge of any youth selling or trying to sell
marijuana, Xanax or cocaine to him or any youth in the
home. He said he keeps to himself and did not want to say
whether he uses drugs or not. He reported if staff catches
a youth using any drugs or with weed, the staff will talk
with the youth. He was not aware of any youth being
terminated from the house due to drug use but indicated it
could be possible.
• Staff 3 and Staff 4 both reported the IL home being
staffed 16 hours per day, 4:00 PM to 8:00 am and
confirmed the information reported by CA 1 and SW 2
related to what happens if drug use occurs onsite or is
reported or suspected. Both staff reported weed and vapes
are things they have found often because of their follow up
after smelling it. Both of the staff reported if any referral for
treatment is needed SW 2 or CA 1 would be responsible
for that.
Additionally, neither Staff 3 or Staff 4 reported any
awareness of Youth G, Youth C or any other youth selling
drugs to Youth A, Youth B or any other youths. Staff 3
reported she would find it hard to believe that Youth G was
selling drugs to the youths, because when Youth G was
living in the home, Youth G basically followed the rules.
Staff 3 said they would find weed in Youth B’s room earlier
on, but not recently. And as for Youth C there have been
suspicion of him using, but nothing found.
Both Staff 3 and Staff 4 advised that Youth G discharged
from the program during the summer, and currently Youth
G visits Youth F at the home. Staff 3 and Staff 4 reported
9

knowledge of an incident involving Youth H and Xanax,
because of an initial reporting by Youth D that Youth H had
taken the substance. They indicated it was suspected that
Youth D had given pills to Youth H, but there was no real
evidence of that. Xanax was never found with Youth D or
in her room.
Staff 5
I interviewed Staff 5 by telephone phone on 2/2/2024. She
confirmed information reported by other staff related to Youth G
and Youth D. She reported they try to crack down on youth who
may bring marijuana or other substances in to the house. She said
Youth C has been caught using weed, but not selling it. Nor was
she aware of Youth B using it, or Youth G giving or selling it to
youths. If Youth G had or they suspected him of such, Youth G
would not be allowed on the premises. She said when others
report a youth as having substances or they smell it they address
it in the moment. They have the youth turn it over. If the youth
won’t comply they document that. She reported the leadership
staff, SW 2 and CA 1 are notified in each incident. She was not
aware whether substance abuse assessment had been utilized
with any youths after these incidents, but TDMs had been
discussed as well as the use of consequences for not complying
with house rules. Level of consequence are gradual, and depend
on the incident, or number of them.
Adult Care Worker Y
I had communication with ACW Y by email on 2/2/2024. ACW Y
reported a brief interview with Youth A who had her grandma on
the phone per Youth A’s request. ACW Y was unable to obtain
specific information from Youth A about the allegations. Youth A
reported feeling safe around everyone at the house.
Reviewed
Case record for Youth A, Youth B, Youth C and Youth D which
showed:
• The youth’s date of placement at Our House as 3/30/2023;
3/29/2023; 10/21/2022; and 11/27/2023 respectively
• Social work contacts showing contact with case monitors
about the youth’s progress or lack thereof in the program.
• Contact with Youth C’s counselor related to substances
being found in his room; and an FTM was held.
• Social work contact with Youth D’s case monitor and a
1/9/2024 referral to CMH.
10

• Case documentation in Youth B’s most recent service plan
for 11/7/2023-2/7/2023 denoting she has been sober for a
few months.
Our House Program Statement which indicated:
• Supervision: Our House will have on-site staff 16 hours a
day, 7-days a week. Our House maintains an on-call phone
where participants may call 24-hours, 7-days a week in
case they need a staff member.
Our House Search policy which indicated:
• Our House reserves the right to search rooms randomly,
regularly, and will search if suspicion of contraband is
indicated.
Our House Code of conduct Policy which indicated:
• Possession of illegal substances, weapons or other
contraband are unacceptable and prohibited behavior while
a youth is engaged in Our House activities. Having such
items would result in a warning and/or disciplinary action
including suspension or termination from participation in
Our House programs.
Our House Mosaic Alcohol/Drugs/ Tobacco/Firearms Policy which
indicated:
• It is the policy of Our House to prohibit and discourage the
use of drugs, alcohol, and firearms; and that house
participants are prohibited from using drugs or alcohol or
possessing firearms while engaged in all Our House
programs. Any suspected violations should be reported to
program staff. Additionally, that no participant will
manufacture, possess, distribute, or use any illegal
substance while participating in Our House program. That
the house is to be a smoke- and tobacco-free environment.
To that end, smoking, inclusive of tobacco products of
cigarettes, e-cigarettes, cigars, pipes, chewing tobacco,
snuff, or other matters or substances use of all tobacco
products is prohibited inside or on any property of Our
House by residents or their guest(s).
Accountability Flow Chart
Medical tracker document showing
• A Lifestance substance abuse appointment for Youth F for
2/2/2024
• CMH visits for Youth D on 12/27/2023, 1/24/2024, and one
was pending for 3/5/2024.
11

Allegation 2:
Interviews:
Complainant X
On 1/19/2023 I interviewed Complainant X, a prior Our House
youth by telephone. Complainant X reported staff at the facility do
not break up fights. Complainant X reported knowing this
because of an incident she experienced there and because of an
incident involving another prior youth, Youth XY. Complainant X
reported when she lived at the facility an older youth there (she
did not disclose who that was) threatened to beat her up. The
youth told her they would get in her face. Complainant X said she
told that youth they would not get in her face; and the staff (whom
Complainant X could not recall) didn’t do anything when the
incident was happening. Conversely, Complainant X
acknowledged that the staff told the other youth to stop what they
were doing. Complainant X expressed that the other youth did not
stop their behavior and staff never called the police. Complainant
X admitted the youth never attacked her; and that the two of them
never entered into a physical fight.
Complainant X said Youth XY could speak to this allegation
because he was attacked with pots and pans by Youth B and
Youth J when Youth XY lived at the facility. Complainant X said
she didn’t witness that incident, Youth XY told her it happened.
Youth XY did not report any physical injuries from the incident, but
he was emotional about it. Youth XY told her what the staff did
during/about the incident.
Youth XY
On 1/29/2024 I interviewed Youth XY about this allegation by
telephone. He reported there had been times that fights had
occurred when he resided at the facility. During those times he
said staff could not intervene physically because Our House it not
a hands-on facility, meaning they could not physically restrain
youths. He indicated the staff would try to get the youths to stop
any aggressive behaviors and if they would not staff would call the
police. He admitted there had been a physical incident involving
him and Youth J but he did not recall the time frame of that
incident. He said Youth J tried to put him in a choke hold, the staff
told Youth J to stop, Youth J did not, Youth XY said he defended
himself then the staff called the police about the fight, and that
was it.
Chief Administrator 1
12

On 1/26/2024 I spoke with Chief Administrator (CA)1 about the
complaint allegation by telephone. CA 1 denied the allegation.
She reported staff talk with youths when conflicts are happening.
She reported the agency encourages resolution and does not
allow or condone fights. Police intervention is utilized when
warranted.
Social Worker 2
I interviewed Social Worker (SW) 2 about the complaint matter at
the Our House’s administrative office on 1/29/2024. SW 2 also
denied the allegation and affirmed CA 1’s indication about staff not
condoning or allowing youth to fight. She reported an awareness
of two physical alterations occurring at the house. The first
altercation was in the late summer of 2023 and involved prior
youths, Youth XY and Youth J whereby the police were called.
The two youths had been arguing back and forth on and off this
day. Staff had deescalated those incidents and had instructed
both youth to stay away from one another. Later that afternoon,
Youth XY became more agitated and got into another verbal
altercation with Youth J. Staff stood in between the two youths
and tried to get Youth J outside to have him calm down. As the
staff tried to usher Youth J out the house, Youth XY followed and
at some point Youth XY made derogatory remarks about Youth J
sexual behavior and Youth J swung over the staff at Youth XY.
Prior to everyone getting outside, Youth J was able to retrieve a
frying pan from a nearby box of donations and threw it at Youth
XY. After they all were outside, Youth XY retrieved a chair from
the porch and threw at it Youth J. The chair hit Youth J on the
thigh and left a bruise/cut. When the police arrived Youth J’s injury
was examined, and Youth XY was taken to the emergency for
psychiatric care. The staff also took Youth J to the ER for follow
up.
The second incident involved Youth X0. Youth X0 threw a lamp in
attempt to hit Youth B. The lamp hit the wall and Youth X0
attacked Youth B. Youth X0 and Youth B were shouting at each
other and Staff 6 (who is no longer employed with the agency)
was trying to calm them down. Staff 6 got in between the two
youths, and Staff 6 was the one who got hit. Youth B was not
injured, the police were called and Youth X0 was arrested. A 30-
day discharge removal was put forth for Youth X0, because prior
to this incident Youth X0 had swung a chair toward another youth.
The chair, believed by staff not really intended at hitting the other
youth, hit a staff. SW 2 reported in this later incident it did not
become physical. The staff safety planned around the issue by
talking with both youths and the other youth left the house to stay
13

with a friend. SW 2 reported the staff always try to deescalates
situations, no one is allowed to just fight.
Youth and Staff
On 1/29/2024 I interviewed Youth B, Youth C, Youth D and Youth
E onsite at the Our House independent living home. I also
interviewed Staff 3, and Staff 4 onsite on this date. I was unable
to interview Youth A.
• Youth A was unable to be interviewed by me. She was
hospitalized and on bed and visitor restriction during the
course of this investigation.
• Youth C reported staff don’t condone fighting, but no one
has gotten kicked out for fights or arguments. He said staff
don’t want to threaten them to do right; staff want them to
make better choices and encourage them to make those
choices. He said he could not speak on Youth D, Youth XY
and Youth J, He said staff tried to help them, but Youth XY
just would not try to do right. Youth J did too much stuff and
was the only youth he knew that got kicked out of the
program. He admitted there was a fight between Youth J
and Youth XY, and the Staff 4 tried to break it up. He did
not recall the police being called then but said staff have
called the police when altercations have occurred. They
don’t just do nothing.
• Youth B reported when youths are arguing staff will
sometimes try to stop it, but most of the time staff will call
the police. When she was attacked by Youth X0 staff
intervened and called the police. Youth X0 was then

Analysis The staff and IL youths interviewed denied the allegations as
being true. The evidence showed staff discouraged drug use and
physical altercations/conflicts. The staff supervises, encourages
and works with youths, and services workers/counselors or
referral services as needed related to the youth.
There is insufficient evidence to support a lack of supervision by
staff.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.

Continuation of the facility’s current licensing status is recommended.
